author: @threeMetreJim
text: This might be interesting to try.  Classifying pictures, by only taking random pixels from them.  To train you'd give a picture, and for every random pixel from that specific picture train it by telling the network that all those pixels come from that specific picture class.  Repeat for all pictures and classes.  To test,  you'd get a picture and sample random pixels, but take the mean average of each output class, for however many pixels you try.  It sounds rather illogical but something like a picture of sky, will have a higher percentage of blue or white pixels and that you can often tell what something is just by seeing a small proportion of the image.  It would be nice if it did work, it wouldn't matter about translation or rotation as pixels are randomly sampled, however, there would be no spatial information to work from. Maybe adding some spatial reference to the randomness (distance between sampled co-ordinates??) could help.  Just a crazy idea.

author: @samuelebrg8845
text: Hi there! really nice video!  I would like to ask you a question:  I am working on Pointnet ( neural network for point cloud ) and I am using two dataset, with one of them I have really low performance, in fact in the training phase the architecture decide always for one class!!  I think that the problem is due to the scarcity of data (200 data in total) I have try to apply data agumentation ( I have achieve 10240 samples) but I have still the same results.  The dataset is  balanced in terms of class (almost the same amount of samples per class)  Do you have some idea or hints in order to solve this problem ?  I can share the code here if is fine for you

author: @sibyjoseplathottam4828
text: Hey Sentdex, Are you using the latest version of TensorFlow. I noticed that you were still getting warning that TensorFlow was not compiled to use SSE4.1 and SSE4.2 instructions. But from version 1.6 TensorFlow prebuilt binaries use these instructions.
